item.title: OS 1.01 - Operating Systems Introduction
item.description: An Operating System (OS) is software that manages computer hardware and serves as an intermediary between the user and the computer hardware. Its primary purpose is to provide an environment in which users can execute programs efficiently and conveniently.

item.title: OS 1.05 - OS Operations
item.description:
Interrupts, System Calls, and Modes of Operation

Interrupt-Driven Systems

Modern Operating Systems are interrupt-driven, meaning they rely on interrupts to perform tasks. If there are no I/O devices to service or no user requests, the OS remains idle, waiting for events to occur.

item.title: OS 1.11 - Computing Environments
item.description:
1.11.1 Traditional Computing

Traditional computing refers to the setup where computing resources, such as servers and workstations, are located locally in a company or institution. Web technologies and increasing WAN (Wide Area Network) bandwidth are expanding the boundaries of traditional computing.
